results.title: Dreams and hammers
results.creator_credit: Paul Tickell, Tanya Seghatchian and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode one of ‘A History of British art’ looks at two extraordinary, forgotten legacies at the heart of the British art tradition: the lost tradition of Catholic medieval art, and the tradition of post-Reformation iconoclasm- an entire culture that was devoted to destroying art. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Freedom in the genes
results.creator_credit: Paula S. Apsell, David Sington, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Is behaviour inherited and destined since birth? This episode from the ‘Cracking the code’ series explores this question with the aid of the world’s largest gathering of twins, English sheepdogs, trained flies plus other animal assistants.

results.title: Body invaders
results.creator_credit: Paula S. Apsell, Bonnie Waltch, Christine Z Wiser, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Viruses and bacteria are able to change their genes rapidly, consequently beating and confusing the natural defenses within the bloodstream. If human knowledge can adapt to the task, theoretically AIDS could become a disease of the past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paula S. Apsell, Bonnie Waltch, Christine Z Wiser, WGBH (Boston) and BBC

results.title: The Cancer hunters
results.creator_credit: Paula S. Apsell, Robin Brightwell, Andrew Liebman, WBGH Boston and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Cracking the code”.
All forms of cancer are caused by faults in the genes. Our new understanding of what causes these faults is leading to revolutionary forms of treatment.

results.title: Designer children
results.creator_credit: Paula S. Apsell, Cynthia Page, Larkin McPhee, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Geneticists can now offer a cure for some of the thousands of inherited diseases. This program explores the difficult personal, moral and ethical issues arising from this situation.

results.title: Accidents of creation
results.creator_credit: Andrew Liebman, Paula S. Apsell, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Cracking the code”.
DNA, a simple chemical, defines the difference between every living animal and plant on earth. Differences arise from mutations; small changes in DNA working as the engine of evolution.

results.title: Birth, sex and death
results.creator_credit: Tim Haines, Paula S. Apsell, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Cracking the code”.
The cycle of human life is controlled by genes. Could genes also programme our time of death, or do they just prefer the offspring who carry on?

results.title: The DNA connection
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Page, James F. Golway, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Cracking the code”.
The Human Genome Project shows just how close we are to microbes, pigs and worms, which may be a fascinating and unsettling discovery.

results.title: The Mouse that laid the golden egg
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Page, Paul Gasek, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Sheep with human genes making drugs, pigs bred for organ transplantation: European and American companies are making such creatures now, but will scientists be allowed to continue to twist nature in this way?
